Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story: I was in the hospital corridor, toolbox in hand, when I spotted my younger brother through the glass doors outside. He was fiddling with his phone, oblivious to the busy street just a few steps away. I saw him move toward the curb, not even glancing up. My heart lurched—Mom always said to look out for him, to make sure he was safe. But just then, my pager buzzed urgently: the ICU needed me. A life-support machine was failing, and every second counted. I could already picture the nurses’ anxious faces, the patient’s family waiting for answers. My mind raced—if I ran to my brother, I might save him from a terrible accident. But if I didn’t get to the ICU right now, someone else’s sibling might not make it. The weight of both worlds pressed down on me, each demanding my presence, each impossible to ignore.
